biography.title: Life Story of Lesya Ukrainka
biography.description: Lesya Ukrainka (Larysa Kosach) was one of Ukraine’s most influential poets, playwrights, and cultural figures. Despite severe illness throughout her life, she created powerful works filled with strength, hope, and an unbreakable spirit. Her poetry became a symbol of resistance, dignity, and love for her homeland.

poem.title: Writing
poem.description:
Contemporaries reproached Lesya Ukrainka for writing many dramas on early Christian and ancient themes, and demanded more works on Ukrainian history. But in fact, when Lesya Ukrainka wrote about Greece conquered by Rome, by Greece she meant Ukraine, and in the drama “The Babylonian Captivity” she spoke about the enslaved Ukrainian people who must pass the test and endure. Lesya Ukrainka took a historical background, but spoke about her time.
Most contemporaries did not understand this, says literary critic Vira Ageeva, adding that in this way the writer also created the foundations for the entry of Ukrainian culture into European culture: “Lesya Ukrainka most consistently, directly, without a Russian intermediary, connected our culture to two fundamental, value-based models of European civilization – Christianity and antiquity.”

The writer was one of the first to take Ukrainian literature beyond everyday topics, which were often limited to the countryside. For this, she criticized the works of the then recognized Panas Myrny and Ivan Nechuy-Levytsky.

hope.title: Hope
hope.description: No fate, no freedom — only hope remains. The poem speaks of longing for one’s homeland, the desire to return even for a moment, to see the blue Dnipro and the native land once more, whether to live or die. Hope stands as the last light in a world without freedom.

green_hill.title: On the Green Hill
green_hill.description: A small cottage rests quietly in a cherry orchard. Like a child, it looks out to see whether its mother appears. The sun comes out gently, shining over the white cottage and filling it with warmth and joy.

cherries.title: Cherries
cherries.description: Shiny, red cherries sparkle among green leaves, tempting little children. Yet the fruits hang too high — the children reach out but cannot grab them. The poem teaches that things grow the way they must: if cherries hung too low, would they ever ripen?

listening_to_spring.title: Listening to Spring
listening_to_spring.description: Spring speaks with songs and whispers — about love, youth, joy, and hope. Every melody she sings echoes the dreams that once lived in the poet’s heart.

last_flowers.title: The Last Flowers
last_flowers.description: Red roses bloom in autumn like burning wounds, trembling with longing for life or death. The frost will soon strike them down, ending their final spark. Let them drink the sun while they still can.

song.title: The Song
song.description: Are there flowers more beautiful than spring’s? Are there years more precious than youth? Flowers bloom only once each year, and the finest years come only once in life.

lily_of_the_valley.title: Lily of the Valley
lily_of_the_valley.description: A delicate lily of the valley grew safely under a tall oak — until a human hand cut its life short. Taken to a grand hall and a lively ball, it slowly withers while music breaks its tender heart. The poem warns: one day even the carefree may remember the fragile flower and realize what was lost.

summer_has_passed.title: Summer Has Passed
summer_has_passed.description: Summer is gone, snow covers the fields, and children long for freedom outdoors. Winter feels endless — yet spring will return, flowers will bloom again, and the fields will turn green once more.

evening_hour.title: Evening Hour
evening_hour.description: The sun has set, the moon shines through the window, and peace fills the night. In the quiet garden, one can forget sorrow. White cottages, nightingales, and the gentle breeze create the calm beauty of native Volyn.
